greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least k such that the k-th cyclotomic polynomial has n as a coefficient.
comment: Suzuki proves that a(n) exists for each n. Vaughan proves that there are infinitely many k with a(n) = k and n > exp(exp(log 2 * log k/log log k)).
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
Jiro Suzuki, On coefficients of cyclotomic polynomials, Proc. Japan Acad. Ser. A Math. Sci. 63:7 (1987), pp. 279-280.
R. C. Vaughan, Bounds for the coefficients of cyclotomic polynomials, Michigan Math. J. 21 (1974), 289-295 (1975).
maple: for k from 1 while count < N do
S:= select(t -> t::posint and t <= N and A[t] = 0, {coeffs(numtheory:-cyclotomic(k,x),x)}):
mathematica: Table[k = 1; While[! MemberQ[CoefficientList[Cyclotomic[k, x], x], n], k++]; k, {n, 0, 9}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 29 2015 *)
results.author: _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 21 2015
ext: Corrected a(22); more terms from _Seiichi Manyama_, Dec 22 2018
